verses.text: When Jeremiah finished speaking to all the people every word of the LORD their God—everything the LORD their God had sent him to say to them—
verses.comment: Jeremiah faithfully delivers God's message without altering it. This faithfulness echoes the prophetic role as a mediator, foreshadowing the ultimate mediator, Christ. See also Heb. 1:1-2.

verses.text: Azariah son of Hoshaiah, Johanan son of Kareah, and all the arrogant men said to Jeremiah, 'You are speaking a lie! The LORD our God did not send you to say, “Do not go to Egypt to reside there as aliens.”'
verses.comment: Notice the resistance to God's prophet, a consistent biblical theme. Rejecting God's appointed messengers is a recurring warning, with spiritual implications about obedience to divinely appointed authority.

verses.text: 'But Baruch son of Neriah is inciting you against us, to deliver us into the hand of the Chaldeans, so they might kill us or exile us to Babylon.'
verses.comment: Baruch, Jeremiah's scribe, is accused of conspiracy—a reminder how the faithful often suffer suspicion. That the word is preserved by an assistant fits the theme of tradition being handed on.

verses.text: So Johanan son of Kareah and all the commanders of the armies and all the people did not obey the voice of the LORD to remain in the land of Judah.
verses.comment: Disobedience leads the remnant away from God's command, foreshadowing consequences. Obedience to God's guidance, especially through His chosen representatives, is essential to remain in His promise.

verses.text: Instead, Johanan son of Kareah and all the commanders of the armies took all the remnant of Judah who had returned to live in the land of Judah after being scattered among the nations—
verses.comment: The gathering of the remnant is reversed by their choice. This demonstrates how God gathers, but human will can lead away from grace if not properly disposed.

verses.text: the men, the women, the children, the king’s daughters, and everyone whom Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had left with Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan; also Jeremiah the prophet and Baruch son of Neriah.
verses.comment: Even Jeremiah and Baruch are taken. Being with God's spokesperson does not exempt from suffering, but participation in the story of salvation often means enduring hardship together.

verses.text: They came into the land of Egypt, for they did not obey the voice of the LORD. They arrived at Tahpanhes.
verses.comment: Entering Egypt against God's will recalls Israel’s earlier bondage and shows the cyclical nature of disobedience and exile. It is a call to trust, even in difficulty, that God’s instructions are for protection and holiness.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah at Tahpanhes, saying,
verses.comment: God’s word comes to Jeremiah even in exile—His presence goes with His servants. This anticipates the indwelling presence promised in the New Covenant.

verses.text: 'Take some large stones in your hand and hide them in the mortar in the brick pavement at the entrance of Pharaoh’s house in Tahpanhes, in the sight of the men of Judah,'
verses.comment: The symbolic action—hiding stones—prefigures the visible signs God uses to communicate deeper truths. God often reveals His plan through both word and sign, a principle present throughout Scripture.

verses.text: and say to them, 'Thus says the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel: See, I am sending and will bring Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, my servant, and he will set his throne above these stones that I have hidden, and he will spread his royal pavilion over them.'
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar, called ‘my servant,’ emphasizes God’s sovereignty, using world powers for His redemptive purposes, even amid human rebellion. God’s action in history prepares for the coming universal kingdom of Christ (cf. Dan. 2:44).

verses.text: He will come and strike the land of Egypt—those destined for death, to death; those for captivity, to captivity; and those for the sword, to the sword.
verses.comment: This triples pronouncement aligns with Jeremiah’s earlier warnings (Jer. 15:2). God’s justice and mercy are both in view: justice for rebellion, a remnant preserved for future hope.

verses.text: 'He will set fire to the temples of the gods of Egypt, and he will burn them and carry them away captive. He will clean the land of Egypt as a shepherd cleans his cloak of vermin, and he shall depart from there safely.'
verses.comment: The defeat of Egypt's idols foreshadows the fullness of revelation when all nations worship the one true God. Cleansing the land has spiritual resonance, anticipating ultimate purification through Christ.

verses.text: 'He will shatter the obelisks of Heliopolis in the land of Egypt, and burn the temples of the gods of Egypt with fire.'
verses.comment: Smashing the obelisks at Heliopolis (Beth Shemesh) symbolizes the defeat of false worship. The recurring biblical theme is that true worship of God alone is central; earthly signs and sacred objects point toward heavenly realities fulfilled in Christ.
